Let $k>r$ and $n$ be sufficiently large in terms of $k$ and $r$. Does there always exist a block $r-(n,k,1)$ design (or Steiner system with parameters $(n,k,r)$), provided the trivial necessary divisibility conditions $\binom{k-i}{r-i}\mid \binom{n-i}{r-i}$ are satisfied for every $0\leq i<r$?

That is, can one find a family of $\binom{n}{k}\binom{k}{r}^{-1}$ many subsets of $\{1,\ldots,n\}$, all of size $k$, such that any $A\subseteq \{1,\ldots,n\}$ of size $r$ is contained in exactly one set in the family?



This was proved for $(r,k)$ by:
{UL}
{LI}Kirkman for $(2,3)$;{/LI}
{LI}Hanani \cite{Ha61} for $(3,4)$, $(2,4)$, and $(2,5)$;{/LI}
{LI}Wilson \cite{Wi72} for $(2,k)$ for any $k$;{/LI}
{LI}Keevash \cite{Ke14} for all $(r,k)$.
{/UL}




References


[Ha61] Hanani, Haim, The existence and construction of balanced incomplete block
designs. Ann. Math. Statist. (1961), 361-386.

[Ke14] P. Keevash, The existence of designs. arXiv:1401.3665 (2014).

[Wi72] Wilson, Richard M., An existence theory for pairwise balanced designs. {II}. The
structure of {PBD}-closed sets and the existence conjectures. J. Combinatorial Theory Ser. A (1972), 246-273.
